reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2012, traveled with family
reviews.text: My family and I stayed at this camp this past August. As soon as we arrived we realized that two nights was way too short of a time for the beauty and the enchantment of the place. It is a camp spread over, under lovely vegetation, the banks of a river where hippos and crocodiles abound. The colors of the sand on the river's banks, the milder climate of the Samburu region, and the overall feeling of openness and ease all contributed to our falling in love with it. We had an amazing driver (Jeremy who is no longer there) who was able to show us every possible animal one can imagine. He knew where to spot one of the only two leopards in the area, he knew at what time exactly entire families of elephants would bathe in the river and make fools of themselves while the babies (elephants) sought refuge under mama's legs for fear of attacks. In short, our two days at this camp and in this area were something that we will never forget. As for the cheeky monkeys, yes, they were everywhere, but as long as we kept the tent zipped up there were no problems. In fact, it was quite a cute thing to wake up and find them on our porch (really, how many times do we have such an experience in our overbuilt. societies?). The quality and the preparation of the food also belonged in a much higher class. Carefully prepared, it was varied and succulent. The wait staff and the helpers were also genuinely some of the nicest people we've ever met. To this day, I still correspond over facebook with one of their waiter (Franco), a guy with a crack-up sense of humor and a sincere desire to make your stay wonderful. I can't say anymore, other than I would like to go back soon. The safari company I used, Shoor Travel in Nairobi, was also splendid in securing our stays in the most delectable and unique places and we are most grateful to them for this particular arrangement.
reviews.title: The most memorable camp of all

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Larsen's is a bit larger than some of the camps we stayed in while on safari, but not huge by any stretch of the imagination. What I liked so much about this camp was the setting under shade trees right next to the Uaso Nyiro River. Here you might find elephants or baboons next to your tent in the morning. You will definitely find the little vervet monkeys "everywhere." In fact you are warned from the moment you arrive not to feed them or leave your tent unzipped or you may not like the results. There is a wonderful breeze through the camp many times of the day. It is hard to believe how cool it gets at night, yet how hot it can be during the day. The variety of birds here is remarkable. For birders, this is a great camp. One of the best parts about this camp is that there are hair dryers in your bathroom. The permanent tents seem to be a bit larger than the other camps we stayed at as well.
reviews.title: Elephants everywhere!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We had a great stay for several days in August, 2012, as the first stop on our Kenya safari. The setting of the camp is beautiful - right on the river with a lot of large nice trees providing shade and a place for the vervet monkeys to play. The sun comes up just across the river - so it made a neat backdrop for some very early morning sunrise photos. This is truly a tented camp experience, so make sure you're ready for that - a large canvas tent permanently mounted on an elevated platform. The rooms are very nice, and the beds are extremely comfortable. You do have to get adjusted to a bit of a lack of privacy being in a tent (which was new for us). We also found out that the monkeys are very smart - they figured out how to open the tents and come in looking for the morning cookies. We had a hilarious start to one day with a monkey "visitor" in our room. We shooed him away with no difficulties and it added to the great stories we will tell for years to come. The food is offered in a communal style - it is quite good with a number of selections - and the staff is excellent. The dining manager and the beverage manager were wonderful. There are people on guard against the monkeys at all times so you can dine in peace in a truly rustic, natural setting.
reviews.title: Glamping

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The game drives were excellent - we saw a ton of different animals, including some we had never seen before like the gerenuks (which are totally cool!). The reticulated giraffe are beautiful! And, of course, as you would expect in Samburu, there are elephants everywhere.
reviews.title: Exceptional

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled solo
reviews.text: With a location and staff that are both extraordinary, I spent 3 days there that I will cherish forever. A tent that faces sunrise and a river teeming with wildlife, I got up one morning to see an elephant in the dawn light grazing along the banks of the river. I was served excellent meals at a deck along the river, surrounded by beautiful colorful birds and what the staff refer to as "cheeky" monkeys. To my delight, meal staff includes a Monkey Chaser, who protects your food from very swift banditry. My suggestion is to distract the Monkey Chaser and give up a roll to the monkey! It's well worth it.
reviews.title: Extraordinary experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Of particular note was Joshua, my game drive guide all three days. He has a remarkable talent for spotting camouflaged wildlife first, and then sharing the experience with other local guides for all in the area to enjoy. His knowledge of animal, bird and plant life, and the rhythm of the savannah are a gift easily shared. Twice a day, I learned to see the world around me with new eyes and understanding. It was a life changing experience, for which I am most grateful.
reviews.title: Beautiful spot

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The staff is so helpful, and as informal or formal as you need them to be.
reviews.title: Larsens

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Larsens Camp was our first stop while on a two week safari. What a beautiful place. The staff was so accommodating and nice. The food was excellent and we loved all the little monkeys hanging around the camp. The tents are very comfortable. Can hardly call it a tent really :) The wake up call service was a nice perk too. Having coffee/tea/hot chocolate brought to your tent first thing in the morning was wonderful. The last night we had cocktails and appetizers on the viewing deck outside the camp. What a great spot!
reviews.title: A very special place

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We have just returned from a safari where we spent 8 wonderful nights at Larsens. The tents were excellent and the views spectacular. The staff were exceptional and made every effort to make our stay special, the food was also wonderful and we could not have received better treatment anywhere in Kenya! Samburu is my favourite park and Larsens is my favourite camp! You are as near to the wildlife as you can possibly be and watch the ellies cross the river every day! We cannot wait to go back at Christmas!
reviews.title: I want to go back straight away

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I stayed here in July 2013. The setting is nice next to the river. We got to see elephants drinking from it, crocs, baboons and the monkeys that are all over the camp. Like other reviews, the monkeys are everywhere. They do not bother you, just follow instructions with keeping the tent zipped and you will be fine.
reviews.title: Great Setting

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2013, traveled with family
reviews.text: The staff is helpful and very sweet. We enjoyed talking to David, who made sure the monkeys wouldn't come too close while we ate, and Scholastica, who served us with a smile every meal. The food was delicious. We are vegetarians and there was always a choice for us. We were never disappointed with the food. Their soups are great!
reviews.title: Amazing location, great service and accomodation

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The tents are clean and nice. The camp runs with a generator (like most places) so expect to have electricity during a certain hours a day. We did not think this was inconvenient at all. You will have time to charge your electronics. The WiFi in the lobby was slow (like most places) but it got the job done. It is nice that you don't have to pay for it like most places in Europe.
reviews.title: Wonderful Honeymoon Destination!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2013, traveled with family
reviews.text: About the Samburu Reserve...on our first day, we got to see many animals: huge heards of elephants, giraffes, lions, a cheetah, a leopard and countless other animals and birds. Our second day was a bit slower with spotting the "big animals" (not the elephants or giraffes), but we got to see many birds. Remember: you are in the wild, you have to remember when booking a vacation like this, that you are at the mercy of the animals, they will do whatever they want. Our advice, don't expect to see everything, so when you do, you will be surprised and even more excited when you see them! It worked for us!
reviews.title: amazing place

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2013, traveled with family
reviews.text: When we left the camp we stopped at a nearby Samburu village. From talking to other people throughout our trip (including Tanzania) it seems that we got ripped off with the price to pay the village in order to to get the tribal experience. For the 2 of us, we paid $100. We heard from other people that they only paid $20 pp. So, keep that in mind. The village experience was great and we do not regret it. We brought a few school supplies for the children and they were very thankful.
reviews.title: Good camp in terms of the property layout

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2013, traveled with friends
reviews.text: First, I recommend that you read over the review written by Obsoperator, dated Sept 8, 2013 for an overview of the camp.
reviews.title: Good Experience at Larsens Camp

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We very much enjoyed our time here and I would recommend it. Do note that the electricity is not always on; one of the other reviewers says that it is (it's very helpful at all of these camps to bring a small flashlight with you, though they also furnish you one). There is wifi, which is nice, though you may have to go to the reception area to use it. The monkeys are cute at first but can be annoying after a while since you have to constantly zip and unzip your tent flap to go in and out.
reviews.title: Outstanding Location and Service

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2013, traveled with friends
reviews.text: The food was good to very good. One of the surprising things is that the dining tent looks like someone just moved out of it. It is plain and poorly furnished. This is perhaps the weakest point in the camp.
reviews.title: Larsens Samburu

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2013, traveled with friends
reviews.text: The staff, outside of the reception area, were all great and we had a great time chatting with them. The only staff that we found to be less than cheerful were those in reception. We generally got the impression that they had better things to be doing than helping us.
reviews.title: Great stay at Samburu

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our guide, Samson, was great. I would highly recommend him.
reviews.title: Well-run, riverside tented camp in Samburu Game Reserve
